content: How can I help you today?

I've been having trouble sleeping because of stress from work. I'm worried about losing my job and providing for my family, and it's been keeping me up at night. I use my phone to distract myself, but I know that doesn't really help. My partner suggested I talk to someone, so here I am.

Thank you for sharing what’s been going on—it sounds like you’ve been under a lot of pressure trying to manage work stress while also taking care of your family. Losing sleep over this must be really exhausting for you, especially when you're already feeling worried. It’s understandable that you’re using your phone as a distraction, even if it doesn't seem to give the relief you're hoping for. How are you feeling about talking here today?

Honestly, I'm not sure how I feel about it. I don't really know if talking about this can actually help me fix it. But I want to try, mostly because my partner thinks it might help, and I really want to figure out how to feel more in control.

It sounds like you’re not fully convinced yet that talking can help, but you’re open to giving it a try because you care deeply about finding a way to feel more in control—for yourself and your family. That shows a lot of dedication and willingness, even when things feel uncertain. What does feeling more in control look like to you?

I guess feeling more in control would mean not constantly worrying about losing my job and being able to actually shut my mind off at night. I want to be present for my family without feeling like everything is hanging by a thread. It’s hard to imagine what that even looks like right now.

It’s clear how much you care about your family and how deeply you want to feel secure, both at work and at home. Being able to stop the worry and be present sounds like it’s really important to you, even if—right now—it feels hard to picture how to get there. What do you think has been the biggest challenge in finding that sense of calm or stability?

I think the biggest challenge is that my mind just won’t stop racing. Once I start thinking about work and the possibility of losing my job, it snowballs into all the “what-ifs,” like how I’d pay the bills or support my family. It feels impossible to turn that off at night, and I end up just scrolling on my phone because at least it’s something else to focus on, even if it doesn’t really help.

It sounds like those "what-ifs" take up so much space in your mind, especially when you're trying to rest. It’s a cycle that feels hard to break—you’re trying to distract yourself with your phone, but the worries about work, finances, and supporting your family still linger. That sounds so overwhelming. Have there been times, even briefly, when you’ve felt a little relief or moments of calm?

There’s not much relief, honestly. Sometimes if I’m really tired I might doze off for a bit, but it doesn’t last long. The worries just come flooding back. I can’t remember the last time I felt truly calm—maybe a long time ago, before all this work stress got so bad.

It sounds like the stress has taken such a toll that even the moments of rest don’t feel like relief, and it’s been a long time since you’ve felt calm. That must be so exhausting, especially when you’re dealing with this day after day. Despite all of that, you’re here and exploring what could make things better—what keeps you motivated to try, even when calm feels hard to imagine?

I think what keeps me motivated is my family. I want to be a good partner and a good parent—I don’t want to let them down. Even though it feels really hard right now, I know I need to figure something out because they rely on me. That’s what keeps me going.

Your family is clearly so important to you, and the love and commitment you have for them really stand out. Even with everything you’re facing, the drive to not let them down and to support them is what pushes you forward. That’s a powerful motivator. What do you think you’d need to feel more equipped to take those next steps toward breaking out of this cycle?

Maybe I need help figuring out how to calm my mind or stop the racing thoughts. I don’t even know where to start, though. It feels like everything is so tangled up—work stress, sleep, my family—and I’m not sure how to untangle it.

Untangling all of that—work stress, sleep struggles, and your deep care for your family—can feel so overwhelming when it’s all intertwined like that. Recognizing that calming your mind might be a key part of moving forward is an important step, even if figuring out how to start feels daunting right now. Is there anything you’ve tried before, or even considered, to help with managing the stress or racing thoughts?

Not really, to be honest. I guess I've thought about things like meditation or breathing exercises, but I don’t really know if they’d work for me. It’s hard to picture sitting quietly and trying to calm down when my head just keeps going nonstop. I’ve never been good at that kind of thing.

It makes sense why sitting quietly and trying to calm your mind feels so challenging, especially when the racing thoughts don’t seem to slow down. Thinking about techniques like meditation or breathing exercises shows you’re open to exploring possibilities, even if you’re not sure they’re the right fit for you yet. What do you think could be a more realistic starting point—something that feels manageable for where you’re at now?

Maybe just trying to put my phone down earlier in the evening? I know it’s not helping, but it’s a hard habit to break. If I could figure out something else to do instead, that might be a small step. I just don’t know what that would be.

That’s a thoughtful idea—putting the phone down earlier could be a small yet meaningful step, especially since you already recognize it’s not giving you the relief you want. Finding something to replace it with, something that feels soothing or even engaging, might help make that change easier. What kind of activities or things do you think might be more relaxing or enjoyable for you before bed?

Maybe reading a book or listening to some calming music? I used to enjoy reading, but I haven’t done much of it in a while. It could be worth trying again, even if it’s just for a few minutes before I try to sleep.

Reading a book or listening to calming music sounds like a gentle and positive way to start creating a sense of calm in the evening. Bringing back something you once enjoyed—like reading—even in small steps could help you feel a little more grounded. How do you feel about giving one of those a try tonight, just as a starting point?
